dataset.title: Pacific Herring (Clupea pallasii) Stable Isotope Tracers: Food Webs of Fishes-Prince William Sound, Alaska (1994-1998)

associatedParty.organizationName: National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis

abstract.para:
This project is a component of the Sound Ecosystem Assessment (SEA) program, a multi-disciplinary effort to acquire an ecosystem level understanding of the marine and freshwater processes that interact to constrain levels of fish, marine bird, and marine mammal production in Prince William Sound (PWS). Research conducted under the Sound Ecosystem Assessment project (SEA, /320) has shown that Pacific herring have significant dependence on Gulf of Alaska carbon. Accordingly, herring are subject to changes in carbon flow occurring between the Gulf of Alaska and Prince William Sound. The first step in understanding how this fundamental environmental process affects herring recruitment is to isotopically analyze a time series of herring for which energetic data have been collected. This will expand upon the data series available from SEA, providing a total four-year time period corresponding to one period in the cyclicity of herring population abundance in Prince William Sound. (Source: EVOSTC website)
-----Funding and Support Provided by: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council (EVOSTC), Sound Ecosystme Assessment (SEA), Global Ocean Ecosystem Dynamics (GLOBEC)
-----Sources cited:

section.title: Herring collection and processing
section.para: All herring sampled from April 1994 to March 1998 for which length data (standard length) were available were pooled and analyzed for trend using a scatterplot and regressed for best fit using R2 and P values. Commencing in the fall of 1995, juvenile herring - < 15 cm in length were sampled at four sites within PWS at approximately 1.5 month intervals between March 1996 and October 1997 (Kline 2000). This four-bay time-series enabled assessing finer scale temporal variability in several parameters (whole-body and diet energetics, growth, diet composition) for age 0 and 1 PWS herring than had been previously examined (Norcross et al. 1996). The - N = 25 from each site-sampling that were isotopically analyzed are reported here with SD estimation. Age 0 and 1 herring were pooled for this analysis since it was not possible to split the data by age and also retain both the temporal and spatial coverage. Thus ontogenetic effects were examined using a separate data selection that also benefited by including data from additional PWS sites (Kline 1999).

section.title: Pacific Herring Collection
section.para: Juvenile Pacific herring (N = 360) and walleye pollock (N = 287) were collected throughout PWS opportunistically during 1994 and from a multivessel broadscale survey (Norcross et al. 1996) conducted from October to November 1995 (Fig. 1). During the broadscale survey, a lead acoustic vessel located concentrations of fishes, which were then sampled with a purse seine (50 m diameter by 4 m deep with 3-mm mesh (stretched)). On the trailing vessel, a random sample of 200 Pacific herring (range about 70 to 150 mm standard length (ages 0 and 1)) and 200 walleye pollock (range about 70 to100 mm fork length (age 0)) were immediately frozen in seawater at each study site for paired energetic (Paul et al. 1998) and isotopic analysis (this study). Laboratory handling procedures were described by Paul et al. (1998). Following energetic analysis (Paul et al. 1998), dried fish samples were sent from Seward, Alaska, to Cordova, Alaska, for isotopic analysis preparation. For 1995 sampling, 25 Pacific herring and 25 walleye pollock were randomly selected from each sampling area, ground to a fine powder, sealed in polyethylene LSC (Wheaton) vials, and shipped to the University of Alaska Fairbanks Stable Isotope Facility for isotopic analysis. In 1994, fish samples were obtained using similar gear and analysis techniques.
This data includes only Isotopic data for pacific herring. Walleye and energetic data are not included in this data set. Similar sampling methods were used for years 1996-1998 sampling.

section.title: Stable Isotope Analysis
section.para: Replicate subsamples of about 1.5 mg were taken from all samples except individual macrozooplankters, since the entire organism was required for a single analysis. Subsamples or whole zooplankters, as appropriate, were weighed to the nearest 1microgram and loaded into combustion boats for mass spectrometric analysis. Isotopic analyses were performed using a semiautomated stable isotope analyzer (Europa Scientific 20/20 equipped with a Roboprep sample combustion and purification unit). A single isotopic analysis generated the following data: C-13/C-12 and N-15/N-14 ratios expressed in standard delta units, C-13 and N-15, respectively, and %C and %N. The conventional delta notation used to express stable isotope ratios is reported relative to international standards (air for nitrogen and Vienna Peedee belemnite for carbon) By definition, the isotope standards have delta values of zero, i.e., N-15 = 0 for atmospheric N2. Typically, instrument replication is <0.2ppt. The %C and %N data were used to calculate C/N atomic ratios. The data presented consist of mean C-13, N-15, and C/N for all replicated samples. Removal of lipid (DeNiro and Epstein 1977) and trophic level (see Introduction) effects from C-13 values of fish made it possible to assess carbon source (Kline 1997). C-13/C-12 content of PWS nekton was correlated with C/N (a proxy for lipid content) and N-15/N-14 content (a proxy for trophic level), thus requiring lipid and trophic level normalization (Kline 1997).

section.title: Lipid-Normalized Stable Isotope Analysis
section.para: The method of McConnaughey and McRoy (1979) was used to calculate lipid-normalized C-13/C-12, while the method of Kline (1997) was used to normalize for trophic level. Lipid normalization was based on C/N using a C/N = 4 as the base level (McConnaughey and McRoy 1979). Normalization for trophic level effects used (i) the N-15 value of the herbivore N. cristatus as the trophic level baseline (Vander Zanden et al. 1997) and (ii) an assumed constant nitrogen and carbon trophic fractionation factor ratio of 3.4:1. In general, normalization reduces sources of C-13 variability, enabling comparisons among species without the confounding effects of trophic level and lipid content (Kline 1997). Thus, normalized C-13/C-12 values of fishes could be compared directly with those of N. cristatus at a consistent lipid storage level. The expressions C-13, C-13', C-13TL, and C-13TL ' denote C-13/C-12 abundance in relation to the international standard, normalized for lipid content, normalized for trophic level, and normalized for lipid content and trophic level, respectively. Whereas C-13', C-13TL, and C-13TL' are used in accordance with a particular data analysis context, C-13 is used to reflect generic C-13/C-12 isotopic trends irrespective of normalization.

description.para: Adult and juvile Pacific Herring (Clupea pallasii) were collected from various sites in Prince William Sound in Alaska during the spring and summer months in 1994-1998.

samplingDescription.para: At each site, 100 fish were randomly sampled and 25 individuals were subsampled from these for analysis. All fish were frozen on site until being freeze dried and prepared for analysis.

project.title: Sound Ecosystem Assessment (SEA): Confirming Food Web Dependencies with SI tracers: Food webs of Fishes

funding.para: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council project numbers 94320-I, 95320-I2, 96320-I, 97320-I, 98320-I, 98311, 99311;Prince William Sound Science Center; Global Ocean Ecosystem Dynamics (GLOBEC)

dataTable.entityDescription: Stable Isotope and Trophic level data for Pacific Herring in Prince William Sound, 1994-1998

attribute.attributeDefinition: Alphanumeric sample identfier used to track samples; those with the format xHEy where x is a 2-digit year and y is a 1 to 3 digit number were samples initially processed by Dr. AJ Paul (U. of Alaska) who then provided Kline with the standard length and wet mass data along with the remaining sample
Calendar date when sample was collected
Cruise month name when sample was collected
Month number (January = 1, February =2, etc.) when sample was collected
Year when sample was collected
Trimester of calendar year when sample was collected, Trimesters A+B = A, and Trimester C = B in Kline (2007)
Date agreed upon by SEA investigators as a hypothetical birthday, used to compute age in days
Data used as the common independent variable to enable merging of data sets used in Norcross et al. (2001)
Herring age in years per instructions from Bob Foy (at the time a Ph. D. sudent of Dr. Brenda Norcross, U. of Alaska ), 0 or 1, otherwise A (putative adults)
Carbon/Nitrogen mass ratio, three significant figures
L parameter calculated from C/N atom ratio from McConnaughey and McRoy (1979), three significant figures
Taxonomic family
Binomial scientific name (genus and species)
Common name
The sample attributed functional group in the Prince William Sound Ecopath Model (Oakey and Pauly 1998)
Number associated with functional group
Nitrogen stable isotope ratio of the bulk sample in standard delta units relative to air to the nearest 0.1
Carbon stable isotope ratio of the bulk sample in standard delta units relative to VPDB to the nearest 0.1
Carbon/Nitrogen atomic ratio calculated from mass ratio, three significant figures
d13C corrected for lipid content using the method of McConnaughey and McRoy 1979, to the nearest 0.1

Trophic level (TL) reference value used to TL normalize carbon stable isotpe ratio using method of Kline et al. (1998) and to calculate trophic level from nitrogen stable istope ratio using method of Kline (2001)
d13C corrected for lipid content as well as TL using the methods of, respectively, McConnaughey and McRoy 1979 and Kline et al. (1998), to the nearest 0.1
Sample trophic level (TL) based on nitrogen stable isotope ratio, to nearest 0.1 TL (used for Kline 2001)
Whole fish wet mass in g in 3 significant figures
Location in Prince William Sound where sampled
Standard length in mm to nearest mm
